BRADLEY AND GORE TRADE JABS IN FIERCEST CAMPAIGN DEBATE 

   (Subs for rewriting throughout) 
 (ART ADV: Photos _ NYT12,13 _ have been sent to NYT graphic
clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling
(888) 603-1036 or (888) 346-9867.) 
(sw) 
 By ADAM NAGOURNEY   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   NEW YORK _ To a chorus of boos, shouts and cheers at the Apollo
Theater in Harlem, Bill Bradley and Al Gore engaged on Monday night
in the most brutal presidential debate of the year, with Bradley
attacking the vice president as a ``conservative Democrat'' and
Gore caustically describing Bradley as a ``desperate'' candidate
intent on tearing down his fellow Democrat.

   The two men drew their swords almost as soon as the session
began, and from there on in, turned almost every question into an
attack on their opponent. It was politics as spectacle, produced in
an 87-year-old theater that is better known for the music of
Charlie Parker and James Brown than debates between men seeking to
be president.

   ``What you've seen is an elaborate, what I call Gore-dance,''
Bradley said in talking about the two men's positions on
registering handgun control. ``It's a dance to avoid facing up to
your conservative record on guns.''

   ``Senator Bradley,'' Gore responded, ``a couple of days ago,
your campaign said that you wanted to get some things off your
chest. Well, since then you've made personal attack after personal
attack. The problem is these attacks don't solve any problems. They
do divide us as Democrats.''

   He added: ``You're sounding a little desperate because you're
trying to build yourself up by tearing everybody else down.''

   Bradley, speaking to a mostly black audience, repeatedly
attacked Gore for voting in 1981 in Congress to overturn an
Internal Revenue Service ruling that would forbid tax exemptions to
private colleges with racially discriminatory practices, saying
that it would help schools like Bob Jones University in South
Carolina.

   Early in the debate, Bradley produced a sheaf of papers, which
he said included a stack of the bills Gore had supported, and tried
to thrust them into Gore's hand.

   The gesture was reminiscent of what Gore had attempted to do to
at an earlier debate, on NBC's ``Meet the Press,'' when he
challenged Bradley to agree to foreswear any more 30-second
televised advertisements. Bradley ignored Gore's hand that Sunday
morning, and Gore returned the gesture on Monday night.

   Gore noted that the bill Bradley referred to dealt with quotas
and that it had been approved by an overwhelming majority in
Congress, with the votes of most Democrats, and, describing the
assertion that Bob Jones University would have benefited as a
``phony and scurrilous charge.''

   And trying to turn the tables on Bradley on another issue of
concern to this audience, Gore questioned why Bradley had voted
against expanding the number of broacast franchises available to
minorities.

   The exchange was emblematic of a debate, sponsored by Time and
CNN, that repeatedly seemed on the verge of running out of control,
both because of the candidates on stage and a particularly rowdy
audience that offered the candidates a memorable image of New York
politics at its most insolent.

   ``Time, time, time,'' the moderator, Bernard Shaw, said
repeatedly as Gore, in particular, attempted to ride past the
deadlines, responding to Bradley, who was by far more animated than
he has ever been before.

   ``Look, Mr. _ Mr. Moderator, and as a point of personal
privilege, can I respond to that?'' Gore asked.

   ``According to the rules the rules agreed to by both your
staffs, you cannot, sir,'' Shaw responded, to a swell of laughs
from the 1,500-seat hall.

   When the candidates were not creating tulmult, the audience
pitched in. When Gore was asked a question about the environment, a
member of the audience bellowed; ``Vice President Gore, if you
support environmental justice what are you doing about the fact
that $500,000 of your money . . . .'' He was drowned out by loud
yells from the audience, leaving the candidates standing in awkward
silence.

   By any measure, this was the toughest presidential debate
involving Republicans or Democrats this year. Again and again,
Bradley attacked Gore as a conservative Democrat, suggesting that
he was submerging conservative views on affirmative action,
abortion and gun control as he sought to win the Democratic
primary.

   ``He was a conservative Democratic,'' Bradley said. ``Did not
support national health insurance, had an 84 percent right to life
voting record and was the poster boy for the NRA.

   nn

   Gore responded by portraying Bradley as desperate and
untrustworthy, asserting that his health care program endangered
the elderly and AIDS patients.

   But Bradley said no one would suffer under his plan. ``Tonight I
pledge that any health care bill that I would sign would have every
Medicaid patient a better health plan than Medicaid is today. . .
.''

   ``Well, that's not a plan, that's a magic wand.'' Gore said.

   (BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM)

   At times, it seemed unlikely that anyone in the audience _ or
watching on television _ could follow the details of the charges
that Gore and Bradley threw at each other. At one point, Bradley
referred, rather obliquely, to a page in the book ``All Too
Human,'' by George Stephanopoulus, Clinton's former senior aide, to
assert that Gore had worked in the administration to undermine
affirmative action. Gore repeatedly affirmed his commitment to the
program last night.

   (END OPTIONAL TRIM)

   The debate was the first in a month, and came at a particularly
critical time for Bradley, whose campaign nationally _ and in New
York, a state where he had once been seen as posing a powerful
challenge to Gore _ has seemed increasingly adrift.

   Bradley's supporters viewed Monday night's session as a chance,
arguably one of his last before New York and several other crucial
states hold primaries on March 7, to effectively put his campaign
back on the map.

   It was the second time that Gore and Bradley has appeared at a
debate devoted to black issues. The audience on Monday night was
almost entirely black, invited by community and chuch
organizations. And the first question was posed by the Rev. Al
Sharpton, who, with the Rev. Floyd Flake, suggested two weeks ago
that the two Democratic candidates for president holding a debate
on racial issues in a black community.

   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

   Gore and Bradley agreed on a few things. They both denounced the
flying of the Confederate battle flag in South Carolina, drawing a
distinction from either one of the Republicans whom they might face
in November. Both Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Sen. John McCain
of Arizona have declined to condemn South Carolina for flying the
flag.

   They also joined, in response to a question from Sharpton, in
decrying the Amadou Diallo shooting case, describing it as evidence
of racial insensitivy in police departments. Both candidates said
they would issue executive orders to ban so-called racial
profiling, in which police departments use race as a factor in
evaluating the potential risk of a candidate.

   ``But I also think it reflects racial profiling in the sense of
racial profiling that seeps into the mind of someone so that he
sees a wallet in the hand of a white man as a wallet, but a wallet
in the hand of a black man as a gun,'' Bradley said.

   Bradley repeated his earlier exhortations of why Gore did not
simply stroll down the hall to ask President Clinton to issue an
executive order, immediately, banning racial profiling. Gore said
work had indeed begun to move in that direction. But he issued the
first of numerous one-line attacks: ``You know, racial profiling
practically began in New Jersey, senator.''

   That set the tone the next few minutes, on issues ranging from
possible reparations for slavery, to health care, to technology and
education for African-Americans. Several times, Gore criticized
Bradley for failing to support legislation that would have expanded
the number of African-American and minority-owned broadcasting
outlets.

   Bradley said on Monday night that he would support Gore if he
become, as many Democrats now believe is likely, his party's
nominee. Eric Hauser, Bradley's spokesman, said Bradley, who had
been criticized by his own supporters for being a recalcitrant
candidate, wanted to approach this aggressively. ``We're loaded for
bear and we're going to go get it,'' Hauser said. ``We've started a
two-week mission.''
